description:
Cognatishimia coralii is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Cognatishimia, within the phylum Bacteroidetes. It is a Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, and non-motile bacterium.

Cognatishimia coralii was isolated from a coral reef sample collected in the South China Sea. It is considered a marine bacterium, as it thrives in saline, aquatic environments.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has revealed that Cognatishimia coralii is closely related to other Cognatishimia species, sharing a common evolutionary ancestor. This genus is known to be associated with various marine habitats, including sediments, sponges, and corals.

The specific role and ecological function of Cognatishimia coralii within the coral reef ecosystem are not yet fully understood. However, as a member of the Bacteroidetes phylum, it may contribute to the breakdown and recycling of organic matter, playing a role in the nutrient cycling processes within the coral reef environment.

Further research is needed to elucidate the physiological characteristics, metabolic capabilities, and potential interactions of Cognatishimia coralii with other members of the coral reef microbial community.
